abstract: There are now three suspected cases in the city. The patients had recently been to China and came down with flulike symptoms.
headline: Coronavirus in New York: 2 More Possible Cases in City Are Identified
lead_paragraph: A day after New York City’s health authorities said that a woman was hospitalized with the city’s first suspected case of the new coronavirus, the authorities on Sunday announced that two more patients also might have the virus.

abstract: The latest cases were 14 people who had been evacuated by the U.S. government from a cruise ship in Japan.
headline: Coronavirus in the U.S.: 29 Confirmed Cases, More Tests Underway
lead_paragraph: The number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the United States nearly doubled on Monday after federal officials announced that 14 Americans evacuated from a cruise ship in Japan and flown back to this country had tested positive for the virus. That brought the number of known cases in this country to 29.

abstract: Despite quarantine sites on military bases and local health departments monitoring recent arrivals from China, it remained unclear how many people would be caught up in the effort.
headline: U.S. Officials Promise ‘Aggressive Measures’ to Contain Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Four military bases in Texas, California and Colorado were preparing to house American citizens for up to two weeks as part of a highly unusual federal effort aimed at slowing the spread of the deadly coronavirus. As of late Monday, though, expectations that a large number of Americans who had traveled to parts of China might quickly be held under quarantine had not come to pass.

abstract: Tuesday: An update on the outbreak. Also: The likelihood of a super bloom this year.
headline: Coronavirus in California: What to Know
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

abstract: A two-week quarantine has left Masako Ishida and hundreds of others dealing with inconveniences and trying to figure out how to pass the time.
headline: Trapped on a Cruise Ship by the Coronavirus: When Is Breakfast?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hidden away in her cabin, Masako Ishida reckons she doesn’t face much risk from the coronavirus that has stalked her cruise ship, forcing an onboard quarantine of 3,700 passengers and crew members in the port city of Yokohama.

abstract: A factory in western France has become an unlikely outpost to help overcome a severe shortage as supplies dry up in China.
headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, Face Mask Makers Go Into Overdrive
lead_paragraph: ANGERS, France — The relentless whir of machines echoing across a cavernous French factory floor this week is an unexpected result of the deadly virus that has nearly paralyzed cities in China and other parts of Asia. The company, Kolmi Hopen, happens to make an item that is suddenly one of the world’s hottest commodities: the medical face mask.

abstract: With infections doubling every four days and more than 600 deaths, China intensified its response in Wuhan, with house-to-house temperature checks and mass confinements at quarantine centers.
headline: China Tightens Wuhan Lockdown in ‘Wartime’ Battle With Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — The Chinese authorities resorted to increasingly extreme measures in Wuhan on Thursday to try to halt the spread of the deadly coronavirus, ordering house-to-house searches, rounding up the sick and warehousing them in enormous quarantine centers.

abstract: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Africa yet, but with steady traffic to and from China, experts worry that the epidemic could overrun already-strained health systems.
headline: Africa, Intertwined With China, Fears Coronavirus Outbreak
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — As the 9 a.m. flight from Dubai arrived at the international airport in Ethiopia’s capital on Wednesday, four government health specialists in face masks and protective glasses worked their way to the line of incoming passengers to check their passports.

abstract: Evacuees taken to Australia’s Christmas Island, a former detention center for asylum seekers, have been given sunscreen, sandals and shorts. They also have video games.
headline: What It’s Like to Be Quarantined on an Island Over Coronavirus Fears
lead_paragraph: Life in an immigration detention center on Australia’s Christmas Island has not been as bad as David Huang feared. It is certainly a far cry from the conditions that thousands of asylum seekers have faced in the country’s offshore detention centers in recent years.

abstract: Dr. Li Wenliang issued a warning about a strange new virus. Then the authorities summoned him for questioning.
headline: Chinese Doctor, Silenced After Warning of Outbreak, Dies From Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China —  He was the doctor who tried to sound a warning that a troubling cluster of viral infections in a Chinese province could grow out of control — and was then summoned for a middle-of-the-night reprimand over his candor.

abstract: The country is scrambling to prevent a larger outbreak even as it prepares for the Tokyo Olympics.
headline: Jump in Coronavirus Cases on Ship Poses a Critical Test for Japan
lead_paragraph: Japan already had several confirmed coronavirus cases when a giant cruise ship arrived at the port of Yokohama last week.

abstract: The doctor, Li Wenliang, had been silenced by the police after warning about the new coronavirus that has killed hundreds in China and sickened thousands.
headline: Widespread Outcry in China Over Death of Coronavirus Doctor
lead_paragraph: They posted videos of the Les Misérables song “Do You Hear the People Sing.” They invoked article No. 35 of China’s Constitution, which stipulates freedom of speech. They tweeted a phrase from “For Whom the Bell Tolls.”

abstract: The virus outbreak has rattled the global economy, disrupting supply chains and closing off access to a lucrative consumer market.
headline: From Starbucks to FedEx, Coronavirus Upends Businesses That Depend on China
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak in China has rattled the global economy, disrupting virtually every major industry, from food, fashion and entertainment to automobiles and technology.

abstract: The territory was already reeling from political discord and recession. Now the outbreak is fanning fears of global isolation and worsening mistrust between citizens and their leaders.
headline: In Hong Kong, the Coronavirus Strikes a Wounded City
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong has suffered through months of political protests. Its economy is shrinking. Mistrust divides its people from its leaders. Locals and expatriates alike already talk openly about leaving.

abstract: OPEC is still trying to forge an agreement on new output cuts to sop up an oil glut.
headline: Saudi-Russian Alliance Is Strained as Coronavirus Saps Demand for Oil
lead_paragraph: An alliance between Saudi Arabia and Russia has helped prop up oil prices for the last three years. But the two big oil producers were not in perfect harmony this week, as they have tried to recalibrate production targets to cope with reduced demand from China, whose economy has been crippled by the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: The United States has no plans to conduct additional evacuations from China though some Americans are asking for help.
headline: First American Dies of Coronavirus, Raising Questions About U.S. Response
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A United States citizen died from the coronavirus in Wuhan, China, American officials said on Saturday. It was the first known American death from the illness, and was likely to add to diplomatic friction over Beijing’s response to the epidemic.

abstract: Xi Jinping has backed out of the spotlight as the country faces its worst crisis in years, reflecting the political risks he faces if efforts to contain the virus fail.
headline: Where’s Xi? China’s Leader Commands Coronavirus Fight From Safe Heights
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — President Xi Jinping strode onstage before an adoring audience in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing less than three weeks ago, trumpeting his successes in steering China through a tumultuous year and promising “landmark” progress in 2020.

abstract: China is racing to screen ever more patients in Hubei Province, acknowledging that delays in diagnosing the virus are a major obstacle to controlling the epidemic.
headline: As Deaths Mount, China Tries to Speed Up Coronavirus Testing
lead_paragraph: Dr. Zhang Xiaochun, who works in a hospital in Wuhan, was in dismay. Her patient had been running a fever for nine days, and a CT scan showed signs of pneumonia — symptoms of the new coronavirus sweeping across the central Chinese city.

abstract: This outbreak has killed more people, and more quickly, than a previous epidemic.
headline: Coronavirus Epidemic Reaches Bleak Milestone, Exceeding SARS Toll
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The coronavirus epidemic in China surpassed a grim milestone on Sunday with a death toll that exceeds that of the SARS outbreak 17 years ago, a development that coincided with news that World Health Organization experts might soon be in the country to help stanch the crisis.

abstract: “What kind of government is this?’ asks a family of three generations sickened by the new virus and desperate for care in Wuhan, the Chinese city at the center of the outbreak.
headline: Her Grandmother Got the Coronavirus. Then So Did the Whole Family.
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — Bella Zhang hung an intravenous drip on a spindly tree branch and slumped down on a large stone planter outside the crowded hospital. Her mother and brother sat wearily beside her, their shoulders sagging, both also hooked up to their own drips.

abstract: China’s leader, who rarely mingles with the public, visited several sites in the capital and spoke to medical workers in Wuhan via video conferencing.
headline: ‘Let’s Not Shake Hands’: Xi Jinping Tours Beijing Amid Coronavirus Crisis
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When he stepped inside the municipal office five miles north of the Forbidden City, China’s most powerful leader in decades pulled up the sleeve of his black overcoat and held out his wrist. A woman in a mask and surgical gloves then checked to see if he had a fever.

abstract: Cases of the new virus on the quarantined Diamond Princess reached 135 Monday, including 20 Americans. Conditions below decks could risk further spread.
headline: Cruise Ship’s Coronavirus Outbreak Leaves Crew Nowhere to Hide
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — In the passenger decks of the quarantined Diamond Princess cruise ship, more than 2,500 travelers are carefully isolated. Meals are delivered to their cabins. They have permission to walk on deck, six feet apart, for a few minutes a day.

abstract: A software engineer finds herself unable to return to her job in Hong Kong after the Philippine government banned travel to the city.
headline: A Job Overseas, but Stranded by Coronavirus Travel Bans
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Jade Doringo arrived at Manila’s international airport more than five hours ahead of her scheduled departure to Hong Kong, where she worked as a software engineer. But instead of getting on her flight, she was asked to surrender her boarding pass.

abstract: Germany and other countries were already vulnerable. The longer the Chinese economy remains crippled, the bigger the risk to the rest of the world.
headline: Coronavirus Shock Could Push Europe Into a Downturn
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — So far, only scattered cases of the coronavirus have appeared in Europe, but the economic effects are proving harder to quarantine. The shock may be severe enough to push the vulnerable German economy, and perhaps the entire eurozone, into a recession.

abstract: A handful of buildings around the world have been linked to multiple cases of the new virus, raising fears of rapid transmission.
headline: A Store, a Chalet, an Unsealed Pipe: Coronavirus Hot Spots Flare Far From Wuhan
lead_paragraph: Read the latest updates in the coronavirus outbreak here.

abstract: A tumble in commodity markets reflects the spreading ripples of an outbreak.
headline: As Coronavirus Stifles China, Economic Logjams Build Worldwide
lead_paragraph: In Australia, after hauling hundreds of thousands of tons of iron ore to China, returning freighters can face a 14-day quarantine before being able to reload.

abstract: Experts find it astonishing that Indonesia has yet to announce a case despite hosting some 5,000 Chinese tourists a day in Bali before halting flights last week.
headline: Indonesia Has No Reported Coronavirus Cases. Is That the Whole Picture?
lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — The family from Shanghai was vacationing in Singapore last month when they learned that the new coronavirus had arrived there from China.

abstract: Steve Walsh, who is believed to have contracted the new coronavirus in Singapore, is connected to five more of the eight known cases in Britain and to five in France.
headline: U.K. Businessman Linked to Coronavirus Cluster Comes Forward
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, England — A British businessman believed to be the source of a cluster of coronavirus cases in Britain and France came forward on Tuesday, saying that he had fully recovered but would remain in isolation as a precaution.

abstract: China’s health authorities have decided to no longer count as confirmed cases those patients who test positive but don’t show symptoms. Skepticism was immediate.
headline: How Many Coronavirus Cases in China? Officials Tweak the Answer
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The news was abrupt and, to some, surprising: Overnight, a Chinese province near Russia, had cut its count of confirmed coronavirus cases by more than a dozen.

abstract: As Americans and others flee Chinese universities, the crisis is severing ties that have historically brought the country closer to the rest of the world.
headline: Coronavirus Forces Foreign Students in China to Choose: Stay or Go
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Word came from home via hurried emails and instant messages to campuses across the country: Leave China now.

abstract: The “wartime” campaign to round up all who might be sick was extended to cities beyond the epicenter, even as it was marred by confusion that has isolated vulnerable patients and left some to die.
headline: China Expands Chaotic Dragnet in Coronavirus Crackdown
lead_paragraph: China’s leaders expanded a mass roundup of people possibly sickened with the coronavirus on Thursday, widening their dragnet well beyond the epicenter of the outbreak to at least two more cities in what the government has called a “wartime” campaign to stamp out the epidemic.

abstract: President Xi Jinping reshuffled the leadership in Hubei Province, the center of the outbreak, installing protégés in the hope of getting the crisis under control.
headline: China Ousts 2 Party Officials Amid Outrage About Coronavirus Response
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, summarily ousted two top Communist Party officials from the province at the center of the coronavirus epidemic on Thursday, exacting political punishment for the regional government’s handling of a crisis that seemed far from under control.

abstract: Two video bloggers whose dispatches from the heart of the outbreak showed fear, grief and dissatisfaction with the government have gone silent.
headline: They Documented the Coronavirus Crisis in Wuhan. Then They Vanished.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The beige van squatted outside of a Wuhan hospital, its side and back doors ajar. Fang Bin, a local clothing salesman, peered inside as he walked past. He groaned: “So many dead.” He counted five, six, seven, eight body bags. “This is too many.”

abstract: Chinese authorities are using infrared thermometers to screen people for the illness, as the devices have become synonymous with trying to contain deadly outbreaks.
headline: ‘Thermometer Guns’ on Coronavirus Front Lines Are ‘Notoriously Not Accurate’
lead_paragraph: It has become an iconic image of the coronavirus outbreak in China: a masked official aiming what appears to be a small white pistol at a traveler’s forehead.

abstract: When Kevin Tang’s American teacher found out he was stuck at home because of coronavirus, she decided to use music to improve his mood.
headline: Violin Lessons During the Coronavirus Outbreak. A Pupil’s Progress.
lead_paragraph: Thirty minutes into the violin lesson, Anthea Kreston knew that something was wrong.

abstract: Despite their high-tech tools, the authorities are mainly relying on a flood of workers to keep hundreds of millions of people from coming in contact with outsiders.
headline: To Tame Coronavirus, Mao-Style Social Control Blankets China
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China has flooded cities and villages with battalions of neighborhood busybodies, uniformed volunteers and Communist Party representatives to carry out one of the biggest social control campaigns in history.

abstract: In China, after assurances that people should go back to work, officials partly changed course and announced mandatory quarantine for people returning to Beijing.
headline: Shifting Ground in Coronavirus Fight: U.S. Will Evacuate Americans From Cruise Ship
lead_paragraph: For much of this past week, as a dangerous viral outbreak continued to rattle the world, officials seemed keen to offer reassurances. Chinese leaders urged people to get back to work. American officials said they saw no need to evacuate citizens from a quarantined cruise ship in Japan.

abstract: Amid assurances that the Westerdam was disease free, hundreds of people disembarked in Cambodia and headed for airports. One was later found to be infected.
headline: Coronavirus Infection Found After Cruise Ship Passengers Disperse
lead_paragraph: The cruise ship had been shunned at port after port for fear it might carry the coronavirus, but when the Westerdam arrived in Cambodia on Thursday, the prime minister greeted its passengers with flowers.

abstract: Scientists have dismissed suggestions that the Chinese government was behind the outbreak, but it’s the kind of tale that gains traction among those who see China as a threat.
headline: Senator Tom Cotton Repeats Fringe Theory of Coronavirus Origins
lead_paragraph: The rumor appeared shortly after the new coronavirus struck China and spread almost as quickly: that the outbreak now afflicting people around the world had been manufactured by the Chinese government.

abstract: The likely postponement of the most important spectacle on China’s political calendar reflects the Communist Party’s growing anxiety over the epidemic.
headline: Battling Coronavirus, China Signals Delay of Its Top Party Gathering
lead_paragraph: China signaled on Monday that it would postpone its most important political spectacle of the year, a sign of deepening anxiety within the ruling Communist Party about the threat posed by the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: The family of Chloe Chang, a Taiwanese woman, is effectively trapped in Hubei Province, and in the middle of a spat between China and Taiwan.
headline: ‘Now We Are Refugees’: A Family in Limbo Amid the Coronavirus Outbreak
lead_paragraph: These days, Chloe Chang, a Taiwanese woman stranded at the center of China’s coronavirus outbreak, says she wakes up every half-hour during the night. Sometimes she breaks down in tears.

abstract: Some factories are firing up again, but with many workers quarantined and parts in short supply, production is limited.
headline: Slowed by the Coronavirus, China Inc. Struggles to Reopen
lead_paragraph: Airbus is slowly restarting its assembly line in China. General Motors began limited production on Saturday. Toyota followed on Monday morning.

abstract: Xu Zhiyong, a prominent Chinese legal activist, went silent over the weekend. His girlfriend, Li Qiaochu, a social activist, has gone missing.
headline: China Detains Activist Who Accused Xi of Coronavirus Cover-Up
lead_paragraph: He portrayed China’s leader, Xi Jinping, as hungry for power. He accused Mr. Xi of trying to cover up the coronavirus outbreak in central China. In one of his most daring writings, he urged Mr. Xi to resign, saying, “You’re just not smart enough.”

abstract: The World Health Organization said China’s drastic limits on people’s movement had helped, but experts cautioned against predicting that the worst was over.
headline: Coronavirus Epidemic Keeps Growing, but Spread in China Slows
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese officials hailed recent figures as evidence that the spread of the coronavirus epidemic has slowed, and World Health Organization officials said on Tuesday that China’s strict limits on its people’s movements have helped.

abstract: The outbreak has exposed the powerlessness of private charities, civic groups and others who could help the effort but whom the Communist Party considers rivals.
headline: In Coronavirus Fight, China Sidelines an Ally: Its Own People
lead_paragraph: Hospitals in Wuhan and surrounding Hubei Province have been making urgent pleas to the Chinese people for three weeks as the new coronavirus ripples through the country: Send more protective gear.

abstract: At a small pharmacy in Hong Kong, part of the job has become calming nervous customers desperate for supplies.
headline: How a Pharmacy Handles Mask Hoarders and Coronavirus Fears
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — “It’s like World War III,” said May Tang, an employee at the Kit Pharm Dispensary Ltd. in Hong Kong.

abstract: But if hard-liners in the U.S. administration were hoping for a united, anti-China message from Washington, that goal has been undermined by President Trump.
headline: Coronavirus Worsens U.S.-China Ties and Bolsters Hawks in Washington
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Tariffs and the trade war. Espionage and Huawei. Hong Kong, Taiwan and the South China Sea.

abstract: The Everything Store, which stocks more than 100 million items, is working to avoid disruptions in its supply chain.
headline: Clicking Buy on Amazon? It’s Trying to Prevent a Coronavirus Caveat
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — What if the Everything Store couldn’t sell everything because of disruptions from the coronavirus?

abstract: Some Chinese business figures are taking an unusual public stand, saying the containment efforts threaten to strangle the economy if applied too broadly.
headline: As China Fights the Coronavirus, Some Say It Has Gone Too Far
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China’s business leaders know better than to argue with Beijing. Leave the politics to the Communist Party, they long ago concluded, and the government will let them make money in peace.

abstract: As the country’s infection numbers soar, most cases have been connected to the Shincheonji Church of Jesus, which mainstream churches consider a cult.
headline: Shadowy Church Is at Center of Coronavirus Outbreak in South Korea
lead_paragraph: Read live updates on the coronavirus outbreak here.

abstract: A look at postponements, cancellations and adjustments made in response to growing fears about the virus.
headline: How the Coronavirus Is Disrupting Sports Events
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus toll has risen to 100,000 infections and 4,000 deaths. With governments imposing lockdowns and travel and border restrictions, sports events worldwide continued to be postponed, canceled or played without spectators.

abstract: A page we will continue to update with ideas for working, at school or at home, with content from The Times and other reliable sources about this global pandemic.
headline: Coronavirus Resources: Teaching, Learning and Thinking Critically
lead_paragraph: Updated: April 20

abstract: The employee worked in recent days at “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and “Six,” prompting a scramble to inform the public and clean the theaters.
headline: Broadway Usher Tests Positive for Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: A part-time usher who recently worked at two Broadway theaters has tested positive for Covid-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus, prompting a scramble to inform the public and clean the buildings, according to the theater owners.

abstract: A surge of risky borrowing by companies around the world leaves the global economy especially exposed to the potential costs of the outbreak.
headline: Coronavirus May Light Fuse on ‘Unexploded Bomb’ of Corporate Debt
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To grasp why the most important central banks — from the Fed to the Bank of England to the Bank of Japan — are now leaping into action as if the world were on fire, it helps to examine the subject of corporate debt.

abstract: Congress and the White House are nearing an economic rescue package; stocks plunged again Thursday despite the Fed offering at least $1.5 trillion worth of short-term loans to banks.
headline: Congress to Vote on Coronavirus Rescue Package
lead_paragraph: Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

abstract: Postponements and cancellations continued in an effort to curtail the spread of the virus.
headline: How the Coronavirus Is Disrupting Sports
lead_paragraph: Sports around the world continued to be disrupted, and even halted, by the spread of the coronavirus.

abstract: Those with chronic health problems are more likely to develop severe illnesses and to die, research shows.
headline: Coronavirus Threatens Americans With Underlying Conditions
lead_paragraph: The new coronavirus is a serious threat to the elderly, as federal officials have been at pains to note recently. But they have stepped gingerly around advice for another group of Americans also at special risk from the infection: those with chronic health conditions.

abstract: When your income depends on promoting travel, staying home comes at a cost.
headline: Coronavirus Is Causing Chaos for Travel Influencers
lead_paragraph: As flights, events, and media trips are canceled and hospitality marketers tighten their budgets over coronavirus fears, travel influencers are scrambling.

abstract: The N.B.A. suspends its season. Colleges move to distance learning. President Trump restricts travel from Europe. What are your thoughts on these and other recent developments?
headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Latest News About the Coronavirus Outbreak?
lead_paragraph: This week, the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak to be a pandemic. And in the past 48 hours, we have seen a dramatic turn of events in the United States affecting virtually all aspects of our lives, from our schools to the economy, from travel to the world of entertainment.

abstract: The Trump administration says Americans returning from coronavirus hot spots are being screened for symptoms. Some travelers say that is not happening.
headline: Travelers From Coronavirus Hot Spots Say They Faced No Screening
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As thousands of Americans flee from Europe and other centers of the coronavirus outbreak, many travelers are reporting no health screenings upon departure and few impediments at U.S. airports beyond a welcome home greeting.

abstract: We asked the experts.
headline: What Are the Rules for Play Dates During the Coronavirus Crisis?
lead_paragraph: Schools and day care centers are closing, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is telling us to limit close contact with others if the coronavirus is known to be spreading within our community. But what does close contact mean, exactly? Should we stop letting our kids have play dates? Is it OK to go to the museum or playground or indoor trampoline park? And what about birthday parties?

abstract: When your income depends on promoting travel, staying home comes at a cost.
headline: Coronavirus Is Causing Chaos for Travel Influencers
lead_paragraph: As flights, events, and media trips are canceled and hospitality marketers tighten their budgets over coronavirus fears, travel influencers are scrambling.

abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the science behind the coronavirus.
headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Coronavirus Hijacks Your Cells’
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Coronavirus Hijacks Your Cells” by Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer

abstract: The president inaccurately described travel restrictions he had announced, falsely blamed his predecessor for testing shortages and misstated the role Google was playing in mitigating the outbreak.
headline: Trump’s False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: As he declared a national emergency over the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump attempted to deflect criticisms of his administration’s response to the virus with inaccurate claims. Here’s a fact-check.

abstract: Scientists are ramping up the breeding of lab mice as well as the testing of primates and other animals, but it all takes time.
headline: These Lab Animals Will Help Fight Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Among the many lessons of the coronavirus pandemic is how close humans are to the rest of the animal kingdom. We get diseases from other animals, and then we use more animals to figure out how to stop the diseases. As research ramps up treatments and vaccines, animals are crucial to fighting the pandemic.

abstract: People over 60, and especially over 80, are particularly vulnerable to severe or fatal infection. Here are some steps to reduce their risk.
headline: How to Protect Older People From the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Amid the uncertainty swirling around the coronavirus pandemic stands one incontrovertible fact: The highest rate of fatalities is among older people, particularly those with underlying medical conditions.

abstract: Empty streets. Shuttered stores. Spain has joined the number of countries struggling to balance public health with freedoms especially prized in a relatively young democracy.
headline: Spain, on Lockdown, Weighs Liberties Against Containing Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The scene is becoming all too familiar, and now it has gripped Spain: Streets are empty, shops are shuttered, families are cloistered at home and the numbers of those infected with the coronavirus, and those who have died, are growing.

abstract: The hospitalizations sharpen fears that the nation’s front-line medical workers could be uniquely vulnerable, a health care organization said.
headline: Two Emergency Room Doctors Are in Critical Condition With Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Two emergency medicine doctors, in New Jersey and Washington State, are in critical condition as a result of coronavirus, reinforcing concerns that the nation’s front-line medical workers are becoming especially vulnerable to the virus, the American College of Emergency Physicians said.

abstract: In one of the most serious U.S. crackdowns yet over Covid-19, the governor ordered most businesses on the island to shut down. Other U.S. cities were imposing control measures of their own.
headline: Puerto Rico Orders Coronavirus Lockdown. Violators Could Be Fined.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Puerto Rico imposed a curfew on Sunday and ordered most businesses shut down, imposing some of the most widespread restrictions yet seen in the United States as a growing number of jurisdictions moved to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

abstract: The court said it would reschedule two weeks of arguments that had been set to start March 23, including major cases on President Trump’s financial records.
headline: Supreme Court Postpones Arguments Over Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced Monday that it would postpone its next argument session “in keeping with public health precautions.”

abstract: The city’s West End theater district, Royal Opera House and other premier venues closed Monday after the prime minister warned patrons to avoid the theater during the outbreak.
headline: London’s Cultural Landmarks Shutter Amid Coronavirus Threat
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week, the lights went out on Broadway. On Monday, London’s West End — the last global theater stronghold to remain open through the growing coronavirus pandemic — went dark.

abstract: How the best- and worst-case scenarios compare with other common killers.
headline: Could Coronavirus Cause as Many Deaths as Cancer in the U.S.? Putting Estimates in Context
lead_paragraph: How the best- and worst-case scenarios compare with other common killers.

abstract: NYT Parenting readers shared their experiences.
headline: ‘You’re Already Worried’: Navigating Coronavirus While Pregnant
lead_paragraph: Brittany Dickey, 33, remembers breastfeeding in a mask.

abstract: The delay in containment efforts could prove dangerous, particularly in nations where the health care system can’t handle a major outbreak.
headline: Having Brushed Off Coronavirus Threat, Southeast Asia Begins to Confront It
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — For months, many Southeast Asian countries played down the threat posed by the new coronavirus. Some officials said that prayer would keep the disease away. Others expressed optimism that the tropical heat would slow the spread of the virus.

abstract: Lawmakers and policy experts say a paid-leave program that passed the House would still discourage some virus-stricken workers from staying home.
headline: Congress Is Knitting a Coronavirus Safety Net. It Already Has Big Holes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus and limit its damage to the economy, congressional leaders and President Trump are stitching together a new safety net for workers who contract the coronavirus or lose their jobs because of it.

abstract: Experts offer advice on how to make the best possible decision for you and your family.
headline: Coronavirus Is Spreading. Should You Cancel Your Vacation?
lead_paragraph: With summer fast approaching, many families are wondering just how long coronavirus will remain at the center of our lives. The outbreak has sickened people worldwide and killed thousands, adding a new layer of anxiety when thinking about potential travel plans.

abstract: Fears are growing about what happens if community transmission takes off in the crowded areas of the world’s second-most-populous nation.
headline: India Scrambles to Escape a Coronavirus Crisis. So Far, It’s Working.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Over the weekend in Lucknow, one of India’s bigger cities, young people packed into pubs. Despite the Indian government scrambling to lock things down, few on the bar scene were taking the coronavirus very seriously.

abstract: Some creators are giving online classes, or hosting drawing challenges.
headline: Comic Book Tutorials for Those Staying at Home During Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: As effects of the coronavirus are rippling through the economy, including at bricks and mortar stores, comic book writers and artists are rallying online to offer activities for those staying at home. They are offering scripting lessons, art activities and even posting some of their own public service announcements.

abstract: The pop music contest, which has brought high camp into European homes annually since 1956, says it will come back in 2021.
headline: Eurovision Song Contest Is Canceled Over Coronavirus Concerns
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Eurovision Song Contest — Europe’s longest-running, most popular and perhaps its campiest talent competition — has been canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic.

abstract: A psychologist offers tips tailored to age.
headline: How to Talk to Your Child About the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Not long after New York City schools closed down this week to help stop the spread of coronavirus, a colleague called to tell me about a troubling conversation she overheard on the street: A boy of about 8 asked his mother if he could have a play date with a friend. The mother responded, “OK, but I’ll only pencil it in. In case, you know, the world ends.”

abstract: The Times has compiled more than two dozen pieces of journalism in “Answers to Your Coronavirus Questions,” which is available to download for free.
headline: Free E-Book: Answers to Your Coronavirus Questions
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 cases continue to be confirmed. By following some basic steps, you can help reduce your risk and do your part to protect others.

abstract: A company that makes internet-connected thermometers has followed the flu more closely than the C.D.C. can. Now the devices may be turning up cases of Covid-19.
headline: Can Smart Thermometers Track the Spread of the Coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: A company that uses internet-connected thermometers to predict the spread of the flu says it is tracking the coronavirus in real time — something that had been impossible, given the lack of testing for the disease.

abstract: In a time of anxiety and social distancing, what can we do to look out for one another?
headline: How Can We Help One Another During the Coronavirus Outbreak?
lead_paragraph: In “We Need Social Solidarity, Not Just Social Distancing,” Eric Klinenberg, a sociologist, writes that to combat the coronavirus, Americans need to do more than secure their own safety:

abstract: Officials announced measures to contain the spread of the virus and protect vulnerable mountain communities just as the ski season was ramping up.
headline: In Colorado Ski Country, the Coronavirus Leaves Fresh Mountain Air Off Limits
lead_paragraph: Ski season was in full swing when the first official coronavirus infection was discovered in Colorado in early March.

abstract: In Florida, where a quarter of the population is older than 60, Gov. Ron DeSantis has started to control public gatherings. But testing has been slow.
headline: A Deadly Coronavirus Mix in Florida: An Aging Population and Lots of Young Visitors
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — At the Florida community of The Villages, the retirement capital of America and the place with the nation’s highest concentration of older people, only 33 people have been tested for the coronavirus.

abstract: If your income has fallen or been cut off completely, we’re here to help. This guide will connect you to the basic information you’ll need to get through this, including on government benefits, free services and financial strategies.
headline: Your Money: A Hub for Help During the Coronavirus Crisis
lead_paragraph: If your income has fallen or been cut off completely, we’re here to help. This guide will connect you to the basic information you’ll need to get through this, including on government benefits, free services and financial strategies. This guide has been updated with the details of the $2 trillion relief plan that has been enacted by Washington.

abstract: The United States and other countries face a critical shortage of the lifesaving machines — and no easy way to lift production.
headline: There Aren’t Enough Ventilators to Cope With the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: As the United States braces for an onslaught of coronavirus cases, hospitals and governments are confronting a grim reality: There are not nearly enough lifesaving ventilator machines to go around, and there is no way to solve the problem before the disease reaches full throttle.

abstract: In Florida, where a quarter of the population is older than 60, Gov. Ron DeSantis has started to control public gatherings. But testing has been slow.
headline: A Deadly Coronavirus Mix in Florida: An Aging Population and Lots of Young Visitors
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — At the Florida community of The Villages, the retirement capital of America and the place with the nation’s highest concentration of older people, only 33 people have been tested for the coronavirus.

abstract: The pandemic has clarified the dark bargain of our internet-connected devices: We look to them to protect our bodies and soothe our nerves, and in return, we hand over our minds.
headline: The Unending Anxiety of Coronavirus Content
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, as coronavirus radiated across the country and sent Americans scurrying into their homes, Rosanne Cash tweeted: “Just a reminder that when Shakespeare was quarantined because of the plague, he wrote King Lear.”

abstract: The move follows other art fair changes, like the cancellation of Art Basel Hong Kong and the early closing of Tefaf Maastricht.
headline: Frieze Cancels New York Art Fair Amid Coronavirus Concerns
lead_paragraph: Frieze New York has been canceled “in light of global health concerns regarding COVID-19,” Frieze said on Wednesday.

abstract: Parents with regular caregivers are facing tough decisions as coronavirus forces people to isolate.
headline: What Should You Do About Your Babysitter During Coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: For working parents, life is utter chaos right now. With schools and day cares closed because of the coronavirus outbreak, many parents are trying to work from home while also caring for — and sometimes home-schooling — their kids. This juggling act is slightly less crazy for parents who are fortunate enough to have nannies or regular babysitters, but these families are also facing tough decisions and sometimes new laws and recommendations. If you’re practicing social distancing, is it OK to invite a babysitter into your home? Should you be offering your sitter time off — and if so, should it be paid or unpaid? What if you’re worried that your caregiver might get your family sick?

abstract: The event was scheduled for May 12 through 23, but organizers said that could not happen. It might be shifted to June or July.
headline: Cannes Film Festival Postponed Over Coronavirus Concerns
lead_paragraph: The Cannes Film Festival has been postponed to reduce the spread of the coronavirus. The event, one of the world’s most important film festivals, was meant to run May 12-23, but organizers said in a statement on Thursday that could not happen.

abstract: Researchers calculated a 1.4 percent likelihood of dying in the city where the pandemic began. Earlier estimates ranged from 2 percent to 3.4 percent.
headline: Coronavirus Death Rate in Wuhan Is Lower than Previously Thought, Study Finds
lead_paragraph: A new study reports that people who became sick from the coronavirus in the Chinese city where the outbreak began likely had a lower death rate than previously thought.

abstract: The matriarch of the large New Jersey family died Wednesday night without ever knowing that her two oldest children had died before her.
headline: Coronavirus Ravages 7 Members of a Single Family, Killing 4
lead_paragraph: Grace Fusco — mother of 11, grandmother of 27 — would sit in the same pew at church each Sunday, surrounded by nearly a dozen members of her sprawling Italian-American family. Sunday dinners drew an even larger crowd to her home in central New Jersey.

abstract: The use of the existing drugs against the new virus is unproven, and some shortages have already been reported.
headline: With Minimal Evidence, Trump Asks F.D.A. to Study Malaria Drugs for Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday exaggerated the potential of drugs available to treat the new coronavirus, including an experimental antiviral treatment and decades-old malaria remedies that hint of promise but so far show limited evidence of healing the sick.

abstract: Payton was tested on Monday after experiencing symptoms the day before.
headline: Saints Coach Sean Payton Is N.F.L.’s First Known Coronavirus Case
lead_paragraph: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton is the first known member of the N.F.L. community to test positive for the coronavirus. Payton told ESPN on Thursday that his symptoms started on Sunday — the day after he attended the Rebel Stakes, a thoroughbred horse race at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark. He said he was tested on Monday and received the results on Thursday.

abstract: Our photographer spent the last two weeks capturing the increasing fragility of New York.
headline: Witnessing the Birth of the Coronavirus Economy
lead_paragraph: New York was still making money a week ago. A few people wearing masks, some closings, but generally business as usual. And then we tumbled down a cliff. By Friday, commuters arriving at Grand Central Terminal paused as they entered the main concourse — stunned by its emptiness, the usual din quieted by stay-at-home orders from companies and the government. For the first time, the vast, star-covered ceiling seemed appropriate.

abstract: Researchers had hoped that antiviral drugs would help patients, but a new study from China said that one antiviral drug combination didn’t work.
headline: A Promising Treatment for Coronavirus Fails
lead_paragraph: Antiviral drugs that had held promise as a potential treatment for the coronavirus did not work in one of the first major studies in seriously ill patients, researchers from China reported on Wednesday.

abstract: Once the virus was here, his response shocked me.
headline: My Ex and I Fought About Everything. Then Came the Coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two months ago, when the new coronavirus was upending life in China, I felt for those living through this nightmare. As the news became more and more dire, I began worrying about the virus making its way to the United States. I cycled through anxieties about illness and quarantine, but my biggest fear was how my soon-to-be-ex-husband and I would handle this.

abstract: Senate Republicans introduced a roughly $1 trillion economic stabilization plan that includes $1,200 payments to many taxpayers, tax cuts for large corporations and limits on paid leave.
headline: 5 Takeaways From the Coronavirus Economic Relief Package
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: Read our 5 takeaways on the $2 trillion stimulus that was passed.

abstract: A new report, sent to the White House science adviser, says the country should not rely on warm weather to stop contagion.
headline: Summer Heat May Not Diminish Coronavirus Strength
lead_paragraph: The homebound and virus-wary across the Northern Hemisphere, from President Trump to cooped-up schoolchildren, have clung to the possibility that the coronavirus pandemic will fade in hot weather, as some viral diseases do.

abstract: Delhi residents are stunned by how blue the sky really is as a strict lockdown cuts back drastically on air pollution.
headline: India Savors a Rare Upside to Coronavirus: Clean Air
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — There are countless downsides to the world’s getting walloped by the coronavirus and being put under severe lockdown.

abstract: Doctors, novelists and other writers are exploring, as quickly as they can, the pandemic’s impact on a country that was among its earliest victims.
headline: In Italy, Coronavirus Books Rush to Publication
lead_paragraph: MILAN — On Feb. 29, Paolo Giordano went to a dinner party in Rome. He didn’t shake hands or kiss anyone’s cheek, a serious breach in Italian etiquette.

abstract: Taking an experimental drug can be worse than taking nothing at all, warns Dr. Andre Kalil: “You are treating emotion.”
headline: At the Center of a Storm: The Search for a Proven Coronavirus Treatment
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Beginning every morning at 5:30, Dr. Andre Kalil makes himself a double espresso, runs 10 kilometers, makes additional double espressos for himself and his wife, and heads to his office at the University of Nebraska Medical Center.

abstract: Workers returning to the West Bank from Israel have been a source of many infections, adding to tensions between age-old antagonists.
headline: Palestinians Fear a Coming Coronavirus Storm
lead_paragraph: NILIN, West Bank — Jalal Zuhair Mansour supports his wife and four children on the $2,800 a month he is paid as a maintenance man for a Tel Aviv housing complex. But on Tuesday, after a few weeks in an apartment his boss lent him because of an Israeli ban on commuting from the West Bank, he called it quits and journeyed home to Beitunia, on the outskirts of Ramallah.

abstract: The ministers were unable to reach an agreement on issuing joint bonds, known as “corona-bonds.” Critics say their €540 billion loan package does too little for Spain and Italy.
headline: E.U. Officials Agree to Deal to Soften Coronavirus’s Economic Blow
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: Migrant workers have not only been victims of Covid-19, but spreaders, too, creating a new world of risk for a vulnerable population.
headline: Coronavirus Finds Fuel in a World of Migrants
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — His whole family back in Myanmar depended on him. But Ko Zaw Win Tun, one of an estimated four million migrant workers in Thailand, lost his job at a Bangkok toy store when the city went into a coronavirus lockdown.

abstract: An outbreak aboard an aircraft carrier has left local officials in Guam to contend with the arrival of hundreds of infected sailors, while they also try to protect the island’s population.
headline: How an Island Oasis Became the Navy’s Coronavirus Epicenter
lead_paragraph: As the novel coronavirus spread through Asia in January and February, Lourdes Leon Guerrero saw an opportunity for her small island. The governor and her lieutenant appeared in a tourism advertisement promoting Guam as an “island paradise” that was “coronavirus free,” and the video was posted to the government’s official tourism website. “Warm weather and warm smiles are waiting for you here,” Leon Guerrero, who has governed Guam since January 2019, says to the camera.

abstract: During this crisis people and groups have delivered free groceries, canceled rent for tenants and called to check in on seniors. How might helping others also benefit oneself?
headline: What Acts of Kindness Have You Heard About or Participated In During Coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: In “The Science of Helping Out” Tara Parker-Pope argues, “During a crisis, the people who cope best are those who help others.” Does that concept resonate with you? Have you ever received any personal benefits by helping others?

abstract: President Trump’s trade adviser warned that a prolonged shutdown of nonessential commerce could pose a more dire long-term health threat to the United States than the virus itself.
headline: Navarro Calls Medical Experts ‘Tone Deaf’ Over Coronavirus Shutdown
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the White House debates when and how to reopen the economy, one emerging argument is that an extended shutdown could pose a more dire long-term health threat to the United States than the coronavirus itself.

abstract: The death came as Navy officials continued to struggle to combat the infection that has crippled the nuclear-powered Theodore Roosevelt, now docked in Guam.
headline: Sailor on Roosevelt, Whose Captain Pleaded for Help, Dies From Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A crew member from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt who had the novel coronavirus died on Monday, in a poignant punctuation to the plea from the ship’s captain two weeks ago for help from the Navy because “sailors don’t need to die.”

abstract: Confirmed infections neared 2 million, with more than 120,000 dead, and the I.M.F. predicted the worst global downturn since the Great Depression. New York City passed 10,000 fatalities.
headline: Trump Stops U.S. Funding of W.H.O.; U.K. Coronavirus Deaths May Be Higher Than Official Toll
lead_paragraph: Britain, with the fastest-growing outbreak in western Europe, has understated the human and economic cost of the coronavirus, according to new information released on Tuesday.

abstract: The Miami police chief promised an investigation after a video showed Dr. Armen Henderson being handcuffed outside his home on Friday.
headline: Police Handcuff Black Doctor Who Tests Homeless for Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The soundless video shows a man wearing a protective mask picking up bags and boxes outside a white van when a Miami police officer pulls up.

abstract: The Spanish soccer club pared back team activities well before authorities in Spain banned mass gatherings, and faced much criticism for it.
headline: Valencia Took Swift Action on Coronavirus, Then Took a Lot of Heat
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anil Murthy had already been facing a barrage of criticism. But as a former diplomat for Singapore, Murthy, the president of Valencia, a top soccer team in Spain, was ready for most of the barbs directed his way for imposing restrictions on access to the club’s players.

abstract: Spraying streets and inside buildings might calm a worried public, but it’s too early to know whether such efforts reduce transmission.
headline: Does Widespread Disinfecting Kill the Coronavirus? It’s Under Debate
lead_paragraph: The images are compelling: Fire trucks in Tehran or Manila spray the streets. Amazon tests a disinfectant fog inside a warehouse, hoping to calm workers’ fears and get them back on the job. TV commercials show health care workers cleaning chairs where blood donors sat. Families nervously wipe their mail and newly delivered groceries.

abstract: New York deaths spike as the state releases a revised count, and California explores steps toward reopening. Trump announces his “opening the country” council.
headline: Coronavirus Updates: Trump Halts U.S. Funding of World Health Organization
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: Most of the big droplets travel a mere six feet. The role of tiny aerosols is the “trillion-dollar question.”
headline: Stay 6 Feet Apart, We’re Told. But How Far Can Air Carry Coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: The rule of thumb, or rather feet, has been to stand six feet apart in public. That’s supposed to be a safe distance if a person nearby is coughing or sneezing and is infected with the novel coronavirus, spreading droplets that may carry virus particles.

abstract: They’ve set up field hospitals in wartime, after natural disasters and during disease outbreaks overseas. But this is a first.
headline: Treating Coronavirus in a Central Park ‘Hot Zone’
lead_paragraph: Rubber boots hung from a tree of wooden pegs in soggy Central Park after being sterilized with chlorine. Workers observed a one-way flow into and out of what they referred to as “the hot zone” of patient treatment tents. Step by step, they removed their isolation suits in a designated area, as a monitor barked instructions.

abstract: Once-fringe ideas in economic theory are now nearly official policy as government borrowing surges and the Federal Reserve signals it could buy unlimited debt.
headline: How the Government Pulls Coronavirus Relief Money Out of Thin Air
lead_paragraph: The United States has responded to the economic havoc wrought by the coronavirus with the biggest relief package in its history: $2 trillion. It essentially replaces a few months of American economic activity with a flood of government money — every penny of it borrowed.

abstract: A network of health centers formed by the Soviet Union in the 1920s is providing expertise in quarantines and epidemic response for Covid-19.
headline: How Bubonic Plague Has Helped Russia Fight the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a remote alpine meadow in Kyrgyzstan a few years ago, a teenage boy killed and skinned a marmot. Five days later, his parents carried the sweating, delirious boy to a village hospital where he died of bubonic plague.

abstract: A New York City doctor on sending her children away while she treats patients in the U.S. epicenter of the pandemic.
headline: Fighting Coronavirus Means I Haven’t Seen My Kids for a Month
lead_paragraph: It’s been four weeks since I’ve seen my kids, and I’m starting to miss them.

abstract: As bleak a milestone in the pandemic as the new figures are, unconfirmed cases are believed to be far higher. More than 130,000 people have died from Covid-19.
headline: Worldwide Confirmed Coronavirus Cases Top 2 Million
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic passed 2 million confirmed infections and 130,000 deaths worldwide on Wednesday — bleak markers that experts say vastly understate the true spread and toll of the contagion because of a lack of testing.

abstract: The move follows a French court order for the U.S. retailer to limit deliveries to essential goods amid controversy over virus safety measures.
headline: Amazon to Suspend Operations in France Over Coronavirus Dispute
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Amazon said Wednesday that it would temporarily halt its operations in France after a court ruled the company had failed to adequately protect warehouse workers against the threat of the coronavirus and that it must restrict deliveries to only food, hygiene and medical products until it addressed the issue.

abstract: Singapore reported a sharp increase in new infections, many of them among migrant laborers. At a long-term care home in Montreal, two nurses, 150 beds and 31 deaths.
headline: Britain’s Coronavirus Lockdown Is Extended, and Putin Postpones Military Parade
lead_paragraph: Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

abstract: Now that the pandemic is raging outside China’s borders, foreigners are being shunned, barred from public spaces and even evicted.
headline: As Coronavirus Fades in China, Nationalism and Xenophobia Flare
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After 16 years in China, a Congolese businessman thought he knew what being black there entailed. He had been subjected to racial slurs and denied apartments, but he had also learned Chinese and made local friends. He loved the country; he called it his second home.

abstract: Rural hospitals have few or no intensive care beds, ventilators or critical care specialists. Here’s how one hospital, with a single doctor caring for inpatients, handled a Covid-19 surge.
headline: A Tiny Hospital Struggles to Treat a Burst of Coronavirus Patients
lead_paragraph: Dr. Desmond Wah is used to being the only physician tending to patients during his shifts at Margaret Mary Community Hospital in Batesville, Ind., population 6,500, where at least half of the 25 beds are usually empty. But he was hardly prepared for the weeklong shift he started on March 20, when the two counties Batesville straddles became one of rural America’s worst coronavirus hot spots.

abstract: No country is really sure how many people it has lost to the pandemic. But in Spain, it has become bitterly political.
headline: Counting Bodies and Pointing Fingers as Spain Tallies Coronavirus Dead
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain is recounting its dead.

abstract: The billionaire philanthropist is directing $37 million of the funds to programs to help at-risk populations in New York City.
headline: George Soros’s Foundation Pledges $130 Million in Coronavirus Relief
lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist and liberal financier, is directing more than $130 million through his foundation to combat the effects of the coronavirus, with $37 million aimed to help at-risk populations in New York City, including undocumented families and low-wage workers.

abstract: Facing a global scramble for materials, British officials bought millions of unproven kits from China in a gamble that became an embarrassment.
headline: U.K. Paid $20 Million for New Coronavirus Tests. They Didn’t Work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two Chinese companies were offering a risky proposition: two million home test kits said to detect antibodies for the coronavirus for at least $20 million, take it or leave it.

abstract: Nearly 150,000 people with the virus have died. A dispute over coronavirus measures in Sudan’s capital has prompted fears that the military would use a lockdown to seize power.
headline: W.H.O. Failed to Tell Syrian Kurds of Their First Coronavirus Death: Live Coverage
lead_paragraph: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息

abstract: Here’s a look at some of the types of masks you might encounter, how they work, what to consider when making your own and the level of protection they could provide.
headline: Coronavirus: Which Mask Should You Wear?
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at some of the types of masks you might encounter, how they work, what to consider when making your own and the level of protection they could provide.

abstract: The French are cautiously considering digital tracking, which has proved effective in Asia. But can a country that so prizes personal freedom and privacy ever accept it?
headline: France Weighs Its Love of Liberty in Fight Against Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France sought clues last month on how to tame the coronavirus, experts looked at one tool that has been central to the strategy of some Asian nations: digital tracking. Citing threats to “individual liberties,” the powerful interior minister dismissed it as alien to “French culture.”

abstract: Ventilators aren’t the only machines in intensive care units that are in short supply. Doctors have been confronting an unexpected rise in patients with failing kidneys.
headline: An Overlooked, Possibly Fatal Coronavirus Crisis: A Dire Need for Kidney Dialysis
lead_paragraph: For weeks, U.S. government officials and hospital executives have warned of a looming shortage of ventilators as the coronavirus pandemic descended.

abstract: Fallout from the agency’s failed rollout of national coronavirus kits two months ago continues to haunt U.S. efforts to combat the spread of the highly infectious virus.
headline: C.D.C. Labs Were Contaminated, Delaying Coronavirus Testing, Officials Say
lead_paragraph: Sloppy laboratory practices at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention caused contamination that rendered the nation’s first coronavirus tests ineffective, federal officials confirmed on Saturday.

abstract: There will be no quick return to our previous lives, according to nearly two dozen experts. But there is hope for managing the scourge now and in the long term.
headline: The Coronavirus in America: The Year Ahead
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is spreading from America’s biggest cities to its suburbs, and has begun encroaching on the nation’s rural regions. The virus is believed to have infected millions of citizens and has killed more than 34,000.

abstract: Buckingham Palace said the queen had also instructed that flags not be flown in her honor unless it was done while observing social distancing.
headline: Coronavirus Halts Another U.K. Ritual: Birthday Gun Salute for Queen
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Queen Elizabeth II turns 94 on Tuesday, for the first time in her nearly seven-decade reign her birthday will not be marked by a gun salute — another longstanding ritual lost to the grim siege of the coronavirus.

abstract: Iran lifts Tehran’s lockdown. Hong Kong arrests pro-democracy figures even as it fights the virus.
headline: Germany Starts Broad Antibody Testing to Assess Spread of Coronavirus; Israel Relaxes Restrictions

abstract: Folks who live on boats face off with land they can’t set foot on, staring down logistical hurdles, ethical issues and social media harshness.
headline: The Seas as the Ultimate Coronavirus Isolation? Not. So. Fast.
lead_paragraph: Simon and Carla Fowler are anchored in their catamaran about 650 feet off a deserted beach in the Bahamas, and they have a message for anyone locked down on land who wishes that they too could be self-isolating on the water.

abstract: Volunteers set up their own roadblocks. Neighborhoods set their own limits. The efforts could help the fractious country battle the outbreak but risk also stoking divisions and xenophobia.
headline: Powered by Fear, Indians Embrace Coronavirus Lockdown
lead_paragraph: BHOND, India — On the long, straight road into the farming village of Bhond, past fields of tomatoes, eggplant and rust-colored wheat, stood a police barricade, an incongruous sight for a settlement so small and remote.

abstract: The pandemic has reached Afghanistan’s presidential palace. Volunteers are stoking divisions as they tighten India’s lockdown.
headline: Chile to Issue Coronavirus ‘Immunity Cards’ to Those Who Recover
lead_paragraph: Volunteer virus patrol squads are popping up across India. Neighborhoods are imposing extra rules and sealing themselves off. In rural areas, some carry sticks, sickles and pockets full of nails for puncturing the tires of cars they deem suspicious.

abstract: An acclaimed young ensemble was making a fragile but sustainable living. Then the bottom dropped out.
headline: A String Quartet Is Crushed by the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Since its formation in 2008, the Tesla Quartet has been showered with critical accolades, released two recordings, hired a manager and lined up a full schedule at major concert halls around the world.

abstract: Lady Gaga, the Rolling Stones, Billie Eilish and more took over the major networks for a Global Citizen event celebrating essential workers and supporting the World Health Organization.
headline: Pop Music Faces the Coronavirus in Prime Time
lead_paragraph: Songs called for inspiration, empathy and perseverance on “One World: Together at Home,” the prime-time special produced by Global Citizen that was broadcast Saturday night on CBS, NBC and ABC and online. Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Fallon and Jimmy Kimmel, late-night representatives from each network, were the hosts, toggling awkwardly between deadpan comedy and earnestness. Lady Gaga helped select the musical lineup, which included Billie Eilish, Lizzo, Taylor Swift, Stevie Wonder, Paul McCartney, Camila Cabello and Shawn Mendes, the Rolling Stones, Elton John and more — many more, since there was also a six-hour webcast before the televised broadcast.

abstract: The spread suggests that it is unrealistic for the United States, Europe and the rest of the world to return to the way they were anytime soon, even if viral curves appear to flatten.
headline: Singapore Seemed to Have Coronavirus Under Control, Until Cases Doubled
lead_paragraph: Singapore did almost everything right.

abstract: Istanbul recorded 2,100 more deaths over recent years between March and April, The Times found, suggesting a hidden toll.
headline: Istanbul Death Toll Hints Turkey Is Hiding a Wider Coronavirus Calamity
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For weeks President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has presented Turkey’s performance in handling the coronavirus as one of the world’s most successful, as he maintained strict control over information about the outbreak.

abstract: Singapore, an early success story, is having a surge in cases, while European countries start to ease restrictions. Oil prices nosedived as a worldwide surplus grew.
headline: Coronavirus Death Toll Soars in Turkey; W.H.O. Warns of Vaccine Roadblock

abstract: Unemployment has skyrocketed, but so has the size of the city’s volunteer pool and the number of people fostering animals. One month into the shutdown, the city is as complex as it ever was.
headline: 11 Numbers That Show How the Coronavirus Has Changed N.Y.C.
lead_paragraph: New York City has never looked so unlike itself. Deserted streets and vacant stores. Essential workers taking to lonely subways. Mandatory face coverings.

abstract: As it confronts the ravages of the virus, Italy’s less developed south also faces economic carnage not seen since just after World War II, with the poor turning to handouts.
headline: For Southern Italy, the Coronavirus Becomes a War on 2 Fronts
lead_paragraph: ROME — The coronavirus was already a disaster for Meorina Mazza. In March, it sickened her brother, killed her cousin and prompted officials in Italy’s southern region of Calabria to quarantine her seaside town of San Lucido.

abstract: President Trump’s move to suspend some green cards could make it harder for many immigrants to reunite with loved ones or work in the United States.
headline: New Immigration Limits Cause Anxiety in Families and Businesses
lead_paragraph: Families that have waited years to be reunited, businesses that rely on foreign workers, universities that recruit international students with the promise of high-paying American jobs — all of their plans faced new uncertainty on Tuesday as the Trump administration announced new temporary restrictions on permanent residency in the United States.

abstract: The test, sold by LabCorp, would first be made available to health care and other front-line workers, the company said.
headline: F.D.A. Authorizes First In-Home Test for Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday said it had granted emergency clearance to the first in-home test for the coronavirus, a nasal swab kit that will be sold by LabCorp.

abstract: In southern Italy, the pandemic is choking an already fragile economy. Protests erupt in Lebanon.
headline: Coronavirus World Updates: U.N. Warns World Hunger Could Double as Global Economy Crashes
lead_paragraph: In Italy, the pandemic hit the wealthy north first and hardest, but the poorer south is also suffering deeply, amid fears that things there could get much worse.

abstract: A 60-day pause in immigration will not apply to guest workers. The Senate passed a $484 billion aid package.
headline: California Announces Early Coronavirus Deaths; Trump Narrows Immigration Ban
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

abstract: These times are testing leaders from the schoolhouse to the White House, from city halls to corporate suites.
headline: We Need Great Leadership Now, and Here’s What It Looks Like
lead_paragraph: In a time of crisis, like we are in now, with people feeling frightened and uncertain, leadership doesn’t just matter more. It matters exponentially more.

abstract: Economists say rewards could overcome hurdles in gauging the overall infection and mortality rates from a limited population sample.
headline: Don’t Think You Need a Coronavirus Test? What if I Paid You?
lead_paragraph: In March, Andrew Atkeson, an economics professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, tried to assess the mortality rate from the new coronavirus based on what is known about its spread.

abstract: After noticing a gender gap in intention to participate, the Census Bureau kicked off a campaign this year to encourage more women to take part.
headline: The Census Needs to Count Women. The Pandemic Makes That Harder.
lead_paragraph: — Maria Olmedo-Malagon, a Census Bureau employee, on what could happen if women aren’t counted

abstract: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
headline: Canada Coronavirus Map and Case Count
lead_paragraph: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

abstract: The education secretary told colleges that congressional relief for students dislocated by campus closures cannot go to undocumented immigrants, even those under federal protection.
headline: DeVos Excludes ‘Dreamers’ From Coronavirus College Relief
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Education Department will prohibit colleges from granting emergency assistance to undocumented students, even those known as Dreamers who are under federal protection, according to guidance issued to colleges and universities on Tuesday.

abstract: No insurance. 64 years old. Alone, along with all the other black people at the bottom of the pandemic.
headline: My Mother Is Busy Getting Ready to Die
lead_paragraph: My mother is dying a painful death, and it has everything and nothing to do with Covid-19.

abstract: The bittersweet joy of watching vintage games during the coronavirus pandemic.
headline: I Miss Sports So Much. At Least I Still Have the 2006 Rose Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The professional basketball and hockey seasons evaporated in early March. The N.C.A.A. spring tournaments were canceled. Major League Baseball’s Opening Day was postponed. The 2020 Masters — the first major golf tournament of the year, usually held in April — has been moved to November, when the sun will dip below the chilly fairways of Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia around 5 p.m. All of these nullifications have destroyed the sports broadcast calendar. The only newsmaking events on the horizon are those that can be orchestrated digitally — drafts, scouting reports, free agency — the paperwork we turn into a circus when nothing else is grabbing our attention.

abstract: Critics say the federal agency charged with protecting worker safety has played a conspicuously small role during the pandemic.
headline: Protecting Workers From Coronavirus: OSHA Leaves It to Employers
lead_paragraph: Adam Ryan, a Target employee in Christiansburg, Va., has felt unsafe at work in recent weeks. He finds it difficult to follow the recommendation that he stay six feet away from others because the store is often crowded and customers linger closely while he restocks shelves.

abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said the state recorded 115 Covid-19 deaths on Wednesday, the deadliest day since the start of the pandemic.
headline: Newsom Details ‘Deadliest Day’ for California
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said the state recorded 115 Covid-19 deaths on Wednesday, the deadliest day since the start of the pandemic.

abstract: Some northern cities have reported fresh cases and put restrictions on movement, a sign of how hard it will be for China to fully recover from the outbreak.
headline: China Imposes New Limits as Coronavirus Fears Return
lead_paragraph: Chinese officials have imposed new limits on movement in some northern parts of the country following a spate of new coronavirus infections, in a sign of how difficult it will be to fully recover from an outbreak that virtually paralyzed the country.

abstract: Belgium said it would start gradually lifting lockdown measures in May.
headline: E.U. Waters Down Report on China’s Coronavirus Propaganda
lead_paragraph: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息

abstract: It has become an act of resilience in isolation, a way to seduce without touch.
headline: The Nude Selfie Is Now High Art
lead_paragraph: Before face-touching became potentially lethal, my friend Dave had a lot of lovers. Now he makes do with nude selfies. He doesn’t even request them, he said. They appear as if by magic: “I wake up and they are just there.”

abstract: A balance can be found to be both safe and outdoors.
headline: How to Save Summer 2020
lead_paragraph: One evening in mid-March, looking to scratch a creative and social itch, the photographer John Martin texted his neighbors in Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., to come outside for a socially distanced photo shoot. The street, he said, seemed to light up with cheer.

abstract: They should have been pleased they were getting so much work. Instead they revolted.
headline: The Day the Household Appliances Quit
lead_paragraph: The kettle was the first to go.

abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said despite a slight increase in deaths from Covid-19, the state continued to see a decline in hospitalizations.
headline: Hospitalizations Still Declining But Deaths Rise Slightly, Cuomo Says
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said despite a slight increase in deaths from Covid-19, the state continued to see a decline in hospitalizations.

abstract: A for-profit company bought three struggling hospitals in West Virginia and Ohio. Doctors were fired, supplies ran low and many in need of care had to journey elsewhere. Then the doors shut for good.
headline: Closed Hospitals Leave Rural Patients ‘Stranded’ as Coronavirus Spreads
lead_paragraph: Michael Nuzum had spent weeks fighting coronavirus-like symptoms — a wracking cough, terrible chills, an exhausting fever — before collapsing at his home in rural West Virginia.

abstract: The tests are not reliable enough to guide policy on lockdowns and reopenings, experts said. But they can help model the spread of the virus.
headline: Can Antibody Tests Help End the Coronavirus Pandemic?
lead_paragraph: A survey of New Yorkers last week found that one in five city residents carried antibodies to the new coronavirus — and in that, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo saw good news.

abstract: No barriers, not enough staffing, low wages. They seem to not know there’s a danger to employees.
headline: I Never Planned to Be a Front-Line Worker at Dollar General
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, La. — I’ve been working at Dollar General here for more than two years. My manager is wonderful, and I have a great relationship with my customers. But when I took this job I never planned to become a worker on the front line of a pandemic.

abstract: Downing Street’s daily updates are worlds away from the White House’s in tone, but they share a purpose: to control the narrative and deflect blame over a heavily criticized response.
headline: U.K. Coronavirus Briefings Offer a More Genteel Spin Than Trump’s
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Each evening at the stroke of 5, a British cabinet minister and two expert advisers walk into a clubby, wood-paneled room at 10 Downing Street and take their places behind three socially distanced lecterns.

abstract: They have launched insult-armed drones. They have confronted scofflaws on the streets. They have gone incognito. And now they will enforce the rules for how Italians can resume their lives.
headline: Comic Insults Aside, Mayors Act as Sentinels in Italy’s Coronavirus Tragedy
lead_paragraph: ROME — In a sort of coronavirus edition of “Undercover Boss,” the mayor of the northern Italian town of Asti this past week surreptitiously inspected supermarkets for the illegal sale of inessential products.

abstract: A Times correspondent, now in New York, compares the fight against the coronavirus with other wars he has known.
headline: Is the Light at the End of This Tunnel the Beam of an Oncoming Train?
lead_paragraph: Having been a war correspondent much of my life, I can’t shake the feeling that the war against the coronavirus is a lot like the real thing.

abstract: There have been some 20,000 more deaths than would be expected over all, and thousands more than have been captured in the city’s official coronavirus statistics.
headline: N.Y.C. Deaths Reach 6 Times the Normal Level, Far More Than Coronavirus Count Suggests
lead_paragraph: There have been some 20,000 more deaths than would be expected over all, and thousands more than have been captured in the city’s official coronavirus statistics.

abstract: Are there moments of “normalcy” that you feel nostalgic for? Is there anything from life a few months ago that you took for granted?
headline: What Do You Miss Most About Your Life Before the Pandemic?
lead_paragraph: In “When Life Felt Normal: Your Pre-Pandemic Moments,” Hannah Wise writes:

abstract: Kayleigh McEnany saw Donald J. Trump as her ticket to stardom. She has been fighting for him for much of her adult life, now as the president’s fourth press secretary.
headline: In Kayleigh McEnany, Trump Taps a Press Fighter for the Coronavirus Era
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kayleigh McEnany was a Harvard law student at a Manhattan rooftop cocktail party in the summer of 2015 when a colleague awakened her to the opportunity that was Donald J. Trump.

abstract: Even as the global death toll passed 200,000, countries are mapping out a return to public life. Health care workers in Mexico, India and other countries are facing attacks.
headline: Scientists Race For a Coronavirus Vaccine
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.

abstract: One that mobilizes scientists.
headline: We Need a New Kind of National Guard
lead_paragraph: In normal times, clinical microbiologists are often invisible. They’re hidden away in hospital laboratories developing and overseeing diagnostic tests, and so are the bench technologists who run those tests. That’s different now.
